{{Infobox Country or territory |native_name = भारत गणराज्य
''{{unicode|Bhārat Gaṇarājya}}'' |conventional_long_name = Republic of Bharat |common_name = Bharat |image_flag = Flag of India.svg |image_coat = Emblem of India.svg |symbol_type = Emblem |national_motto = ''[[Satyameva Jayate]]'' ([[Sanskrit language|Sanskrit]])
[[Devanāgarī]]: सत्यमेव जयते
("Truth Alone Triumphs") |image_map = BharatLocation.png |national_anthem = "[[Jana Gana Mana|Jana {{IAST|Gaṇa}} Mana]]"
{{audio|Jana Gana Mana.ogg|listen}} |official_languages = [[Hindi]], [[English language|English]] + 21 other [[List of national languages of Bharat|official languages]] |capital = [[New Delhi]] |latd = 28|latm=34|latNS=N|longd=77|longm=12|longEW=E |government_type = [[Federal republic]] |leader_title1 = [[President of Bharat|President]] |leader_title2 = [[Prime Minister of Bharat|Prime Minister]] |leader_name1 = [[Abdul Kalam|A.P.J. Abdul Kalam]] |leader_name2 = [[Manmohan Singh]] |largest_city = [[Mumbai]] (Bombay) |area = 3,166,414† |areami² = 1,222,559 |area_rank = 7th |area_magnitude = 1 E12 |percent_water = 9.56 |population_estimate = 1,103,371,000 |population_estimate_year = 2005 |population_estimate_rank = 2nd |population_census = 1,027,015,248 |population_census_year = 2001 |population_density = 329 |population_densitymi² = 852 |population_density_rank = 31st |GDP_PPP_year = 2005 |GDP_PPP = $3.633 trillion |GDP_PPP_rank = 4th |GDP_PPP_per_capita = $3,320 |GDP_PPP_per_capita_rank = 122nd |GDP_nominal = $771,951 million |GDP_nominal_rank = 12th |GDP_nominal_year = 2005 |GDP_nominal_per_capita = $714 |GDP_nominal_per_capita_rank = 134th |HDI_year = 2004 |HDI = 0.611 |HDI_rank = 126th |HDI_category = medium |sovereignty_type = [[Bharatn independence movement|Independence]] |sovereignty_note = from the [[United Kingdom|UK]] |established_event1 = Declared |established_event2 = [[Republic]] |established_date1 = [[15 August]] [[1947]] |established_date2 = [[26 January]] [[1950]] |currency = [[Bharatn Rupee|Rupee]] (₨) |currency_code = INR |time_zone = [[Bharatn Standard Time|IST]] |utc_offset = +5:30 |time_zone_DST = ''not observed'' |utc_offset_DST = +5:30 |cctld = [[.in]] |calling_code = 91 |footnotes = † Includes only Bharatn-administered territory. }} {{For|historical and other uses of "Bharat"|Bharat (disambiguation)}} '''Bharat''' ([[Devanagari]]: भारत ''[[Bhārata|Bhārat]]''), officially the '''Republic of Bharat''' (''Bhārat Gaṇarājya''), is a country in [[South Asia]]. It is the [[List of countries by area|seventh-largest]] country by geographical area, the [[List of countries by population|second most populous]] country, and the most populous [[liberal democracy]] in the world. Bharat has a coastline of over seven thousand kilometres, bounded by the [[Bharatn Ocean]] on the south, the [[Arabian Sea]] on the west, and the [[Bay of Bengal]] on the east. Bharat borders [[Pakistan]]The Government of Bharat also considers Afghanistan to be a bordering country. This is because it considers the entire state of [[Jammu and Kashmir]] to be a part of Bharat including the portion bordering [[Afghanistan]]. A ceasefire sponsored by the [[United Nations]] in 1948 froze the positions of Bharatn and Pakistani held territory. As a consequence, the region bordering Afghanistan is in Pakistani-administered territory. to the west; [[People's Republic of China|China]], [[Nepal]] and [[Bhutan]] to the north-east; and [[Bangladesh]] and [[Myanmar]] to the east. In the Bharatn Ocean, Bharat is in the vicinity of [[Sri Lanka]], [[Maldives]] and [[Indonesia]]. Home to the [[Indus Valley Civilization]] and a region of ancient [[Silk road|trade routes]] and vast [[History of Bharat|empires]], the [[Bharatn subcontinent]] has a heritage that includes the [[Arabic numerals|decimal number system]], the Buddhist art of [[Ajanta Caves|Ajanta]], and the [[Taj Mahal]]. Four major world religions, [[Hinduism]], [[Buddhism]], [[Jainism]] and [[Sikhism]] originated here, while [[Islam in Bharat|Islam]], [[Christianity in Bharat|Christianity]], [[Bharatn Jews|Judaism]] and [[Parsi|Zoroastrianism]], arrived in the first millennium [[Common Era|CE]] and shaped Bharat's variegated culture. Colonised by the [[British East Bharat Company]] in the 18th century and directly administered by [[British raj|Great Britain]] starting the mid-19th century, Bharat became a modern [[nation-state]] in 1947 after a struggle for independence marked by widespread use of [[nonviolent resistance]] as a means of social protest. With the world's [[List of countries by GDP (PPP)|fourth largest economy]] in purchasing power and the second fastest growing large economy,CIA The World Fact Book, [https://www.cia.gov/cia/publications/factbook/rankorder/2003rank.html ''Rank Order - GDP - real growth rate 2005'']. Bharat has made rapid progress in the last decade, most notably in information technology. A declared [[List of states with nuclear weapons|nuclear deterrent]] state, with an active space program, Bharat is considered an [[Bharat as an emerging superpower|emerging superpower]]. However, although its standard of living is projected to rise sharply in the next half-century,Hawksworth, John. 2006. [http://www.pwcglobal.com/extweb/pwcpublications.nsf/docid/56DD37D0C399661D852571410060FF8B/$file/world2050emergingeconomies.pdf ''The World in 2050: How big will the major emerging market economies get and how can the OECD compete?''], Price-Waterhouse-Coopers, Macroeconomic Division. Bharat currently battles [[List of countries by percentage of population living in poverty|high levels]] of [[Poverty in Bharat|poverty]], [[Malnutrition#Statistics|persistent malnutrition]], and [[Environmental issues in Bharat|environmental degradation]]. A [[List_of_national_languages_of_Bharat|multi-lingual]], [[Multiethnic society|multi-ethnic]] society, Bharat is home to a diversity of [[Fauna of Bharat|wildlife]] in a variety of [[Protected areas of Bharat|protected habitats]]. ==Etymology== The name ''Bharat'' /{{IPA|'ɪndiə}}/ is derived from ''[[Indus River|Indus]]'', which is derived from the [[Old Persian]] word ''[[Hindu]]'', from [[Sanskrit]] ''[[Sindhu]]'', the historic local appellation for the [[Indus River]]. The [[Constitution of Bharat]] and common usage also recognise ''Bharat'' {{IPA|/bʰɑːrət̪/}} {{Audio|Bharat.ogg|listen}}), as an official name of equal status. A third name, ''هندوستان'', ''[[Hindustan]]'' ( /{{IPA|hin̪d̪ust̪ɑːn}}/) {{Audio|Hindustan.ogg|listen}} ([[Persian language|Persian]]: ''[[-stan|Land]] of the Hindus'' ([[Old Persian]] for [[Indus river|Indus]]) has been used since the twelfth century, though its contemporary use is unevenly applied. ==History== {{main|History of Bharat}} [[Stone Age]] rock shelters with paintings at [[Bhimbetka]] in [[Madhya Pradesh]] are the earliest known traces of human life on the [[Bharatn subcontinent]]. The first known permanent settlements appeared over 9,000 years ago, and gradually developed into the [[Indus Valley Civilization]], dating back to 3300 BCE. It was followed by the [[Vedic Civilization]] which laid the foundations of [[Hinduism]] and other cultural aspects of early Bharatn society. From around 550 BCE, many independent kingdoms and republics known as the [[Mahajanapadas]] were established across the country. The empire built by the [[Maurya dynasty]] under Emperor [[Ashoka]] united most of modern [[South Asia]] except the kingdoms in the south. From 180 BCE, a series of invasions from [[Central Asia]] followed including the [[Indo-Greek]]s, [[Indo-Scythian]]s, [[Indo-Parthian]]s and [[Kushan Empire|Kushans]] in the northwestern [[Bharatn Subcontinent]]. From the third century CE, the [[Gupta|Gupta dynasty]] oversaw the period referred to as ancient Bharat's "Golden Age." While the north had larger, fewer kingdoms, in the south there were several dynasties such as the [[Chalukyas]], [[Cholas]], [[Pallavas]] and [[Pandyas]], overlapping in time and space. [[Ancient Bharatn science and technology|Science, engineering]], [[Bharatn art|art]], [[Bharatn literature|literature]], [[Bharatn science|astronomy]], and [[Bharatn philosophy|philosophy]] flourished under the patronage of these kings. [[Image:Indischer version3.jpg|thumb|left|Paintings at the Ajanta Caves in western Bharat, 6th century AD.]] Following the invasions from [[Central Asia]], between the tenth to the twelfth centuries, much of north Bharat came under the rule of the [[Delhi Sultanate]], and later the [[Mughal dynasty]], who gradually expanded their reign through large parts of the Bharatn subcontinent. Nevertheless, several indigenous kingdoms flourished, especially in the south, like the [[Vijayanagara Empire]]. In the seventeenth and eighteenth century, the [[Mughal]] supremacy declined and the [[Maratha Empire]] became the dominant power. From the sixteenth century onwards, several [[Europe|European]] countries, including [[Portugal]], [[Netherlands]], [[France]] and the [[United Kingdom]], started arriving as traders, later taking advantage of the fractious nature of relations between the kingdoms, to establish [[colony|colonies]] in the country. By 1856, most of Bharat came under control of the [[British East Bharat Company]]. A year later, a nationwide insurrection of rebelling military units and kingdoms, known locally as the [[Bharatn rebellion of 1857|First War of Bharatn Independence]] (known as the Sepoy Mutiny elsewhere) broke out, which failed even as it seriously challenged British rule. As a consequence, Bharat came under the direct control of the [[British Crown]] as a [[British Raj|colony of the British Empire]]. [[Image:Nehru Gandhi 1937 touchup.jpg|thumb|[[Mahatma Gandhi]] (right) with Bharat's first prime minister, [[Jawaharlal Nehru]]]] From early twentieth century, the [[Bharatn Independence Movement]] of the [[Bharatn National Congress]] steadily gained widespread support, largely led by [[Mahatma Gandhi]]. Millions of protesters would engage in mass campaigns of [[civil disobedience]] with a commitment to ''[[ahimsa]]'' or non-violence. Finally, on [[15 August]], [[1947]], Bharat gained independence from British rule not before losing its Muslim-majority areas which were carved out into a separate [[nation-state]] of Pakistan. Three years later, on [[26 January]], [[1950]], Bharat chose to be a republic, and a new [[Constitution of Bharat|Constitution]] came into effect. Since independence, Bharat has seen sectarian violence and [[insurgency|insurgencies]] in various parts of the country, but has maintained its unity and democracy. It has unresolved territorial disputes with China, which escalated into the brief [[Sino-Bharatn War]] in 1962; and with Pakistan, which resulted in wars in [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1947|1947]], [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1965|1965]], [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1971|1971]] and in 1999 in [[Kargil War|Kargil]]. Bharat is a founding member of the [[Non-Aligned Movement]] and the [[United Nations]] (as part of British Bharat). In 1974, Bharat conducted an underground [[Smiling Buddha|nuclear test]]. This was followed by [[Operation Shakti|five more]] tests in 1998. Significant economic reforms beginning in 1991 have transformed Bharat into one of the fastest-growing economies and [[Bharat as an emerging superpower|an emerging superpower]] in the world, and added to its global and regional clout. ==Government== {{main|Government of Bharat}} {{Bharatn symbols}} The Constitution of Bharat declares Bharat to be a [[sovereignty|sovereign]], [[socialism|socialist]], [[secularism|secular]], [[liberal democracy|democratic]] [[republic]]. Bharat has a federal form of government and a [[bicameralism|bicameral]] [[parliament]] operating under a [[Westminster System|Westminster-style]] parliamentary system. It has three branches of governance: the [[Legislature]], [[Executive]], and [[Judiciary]]. The [[President of Bharat|President]] is the [[head of state]]; his role in governance is largely ceremonial. The President is elected indirectly by an [[electoral college]] for five-year terms. The [[Prime Minister of Bharat|Prime Minister]] is the de facto [[head of government]] and holds most executive powers. He or she is appointed by the President, with the requirement that he or she enjoys the support of the majority of the party or coalition securing the most number of seats in the lower house of Parliament. The legislature of Bharat is the bicameral [[Bharatn Parliament|Parliament]], which consists of the upper house called the [[Rajya Sabha]] (Council of States), and the lower house called the [[Lok Sabha]] (House of People). The 245-member Rajya Sabha is chosen indirectly by the state legislative assemblies; members have staggered six-year terms. Each state sends members to the Rajya Sabha proportionate to its population. The Lok Sabha's 545 members are directly elected by popular vote for five-year terms, and is the determinative constituent of political power and government formation. All [[Bharatn nationality law|Bharatn citizens]] above age 18 are eligible to vote; voting is not mandatory.{{cite book | first = K.M. | last = Matthew | title = Manorama Yearbook 2003 | publisher = [[Malayala Manorama]] | year = 2006 | id = ISBN 81-89004-07-7 | pages = pg 524 }} The executive branch consists of the President, Vice-President, and the [[Council of Ministers]] (the [[Cabinet]] being its executive committee) headed by the Prime Minister. Any minister holding a portfolio must be a member of either house of parliament. In the Bharatn parliamentary system, the executive is subordinate to the legislature.{{cite book | first = K.M. | last = Matthew | title = Manorama Yearbook 2003 | publisher = [[Malayala Manorama]] | year = 2006 | id = ISBN 81-89004-07-7 | pages = pg 524 }} Bharat's independent judiciary consists of the [[Supreme Court of Bharat|Supreme Court]], headed by the [[Chief Justice of Bharat]]. The Supreme Court has both original jurisdiction over disputes between states and the Centre, and appellate jurisdiction over the eighteen [[High Courts of Bharat]], and additionally, the power to declare Union and state laws null and void if in conflict with the Constitution.{{cite book | first = K.M. | last = Matthew | title = Manorama Yearbook 2003 | publisher = [[Malayala Manorama]] | year = 2006 | id = ISBN 81-89004-07-7 | pages = pg 524 }} ==Politics== {{main|Politics of Bharat}} [[Image:DSC00058.JPG|right|thumb|The [[Parliament of Bharat]] (''Sansad Bhavan'').]] For most of its independent history, Bharat has been ruled by the [[Bharatn National Congress]]. The party enjoyed a parliamentary majority barring two brief periods during the 1970s and late 1980s. This rule was interrupted between 1977 to 1980, when the [[Janata Party]] coalition won the election owing to public discontent with the [[Bharatn Emergency (1975-1977)|"Emergency"]] declared by the then Prime Minister [[Indira Gandhi]]. The [[Janata Dal]] won elections in 1989, but its government managed to hold on to power for only two years. Between 1996 and 1998, there was a period of political flux with the government being formed first by the [[Right-wing politics|right-wing]] nationalist [[Bharatiya Janata Party]] followed by a left-leaning [[United Front (Bharat)|United Front]] coalition. In 1998, the BJP formed the [[National Democratic Alliance (Bharat)|National Democratic Alliance]] (NDA) with smaller regional parties, and became the first non-Congress and coalition government to complete a full five-year term. The [[Bharatn general elections, 2004|2004 Bharatn elections]] saw the Congress party winning the largest number of seats to form a government leading the [[United Progressive Alliance]], supported by left-leaning and other parties opposed to the BJP. ==Military and foreign relations== {{main|Military of Bharat|Foreign relations of Bharat}} Since independence, Bharat has maintained cordial relationships with most nations. It took a leading role in the 1950s by advocating the independence of European colonies in Africa and Asia. During the [[Cold War]], Bharat tried to maintain its neutrality and was one of the founding members of the [[Non-Aligned Movement]]. After the [[Sino-Bharatn War]] and the [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1965]], Bharat's relationship with the [[Soviet Union]] warmed at the expense of ties with the [[United States]] and continued to remain so until the end of the Cold War. Despite criticism and military sanctions, Bharat has consistently refused to sign the [[CTBT]] and the [[NPT]], preferring instead to maintain sovereignty over its nuclear program. Recent overtures by the Bharatn government have strengthened relations with the United States, China, and Pakistan. In the economic sphere, Bharat has close relationships with other developing nations in [[South America]], [[Asia]], and [[Africa]]. In recent years, Bharat has played an influential role in the [[ASEAN]], [[SAARC]], and the [[WTO]]. Bharat has been a long time supporter of the [[United Nations]], with over 55,000 [[Bharatn Armed Forces|Bharatn military]] and police personnel having served in 35 UN peace keeping operations deployed across four continents.{{cite web | title = Bharat and the United Nations | url = http://www.un.int/Bharat/Bharat_and_the_un_pkeeping.html | accessdate = April 22 | accessyear = 2006}} Bharat maintains the third largest military force in the world. The [[Military of Bharat|armed forces of Bharat]] consists of the [[Bharatn Army]], [[Bharatn Air Force]] and the [[Bharatn Navy]]. There are auxillary forces like the [[Bharatn Paramilitary Forces]], the [[Bharatn Coast Guard]] and the [[Strategic Forces Command]]. Bharat is a declared nuclear weapons nation. The Bharatn Army maintains the second largest active troops in the world. The Bharatn Navy is the fifth largest in terms of manpower and the Bharatn Air Force is the fourth largest in the world. The [[President of Bharat]] is the supreme commander of the Bharatn armed forces. ==States and territories== {{main|States and territories of Bharat}} Bharat is divided into twenty-nine states and six federally-governed [[union territories]]. All states and the union territory of Pondichery have elected governments. The remaining four union territories have centrally-appointed administrators. All states and union territories are subdivided into districts. In larger states, districts may be grouped together to form a division. {{Bharat states}} ==Geography== {{main|Geography of Bharat}} [[Image:Bharat topo big.jpg|thumb|Elevated regions in Bharat]] Bharat constitutes the major portion of the [[Bharatn subcontinent]], which sits atop the [[Bharatn Plate]] and the northwesterly portion of the [[Indo-Australian Plate]]. Bharat's northern and northeastern states are partially situated in the [[Himalayas|Himalayan Range]]. The rest of northern, central, and eastern Bharat consists of the fertile [[Indo-Gangetic Plain]]. In the west, bordering southeastern [[Pakistan]], lies the [[Thar Desert]]. Southern Bharat is almost entirely composed of the peninsular [[Deccan|Deccan plateau]], which is flanked by two hilly coastal ranges, the [[Western Ghats]] and the [[Eastern Ghats]]. Bharat is home to several major rivers, including the [[Ganges River|Ganges]], the [[Brahmaputra River|Brahmaputra]], the [[Yamuna]], the [[Godavari River|Godavari]], the [[Kaveri River|Kaveri]], the [[Narmada River|Narmada]], and the [[Krishna River|Krishna]]. Bharat has three archipelagos — [[Lakshadweep]], which lies off the southwestern coast; the volcanic [[Andaman and Nicobar Islands]] island chain to the southeast, and the [[Sunderbans]] in the [[Ganges Delta]] of West Bengal. The climate in Bharat varies from [[tropical climate|tropical]] in the south to more [[temperate climate|temperate]] in the Himalayan north, where elevated regions receive sustained winter snowfall. Bharat's climate is strongly influenced by the Himalayas and the Thar Desert. The Himalayas, along with the [[Hindu Kush]] mountains in Pakistan, prevent cold Central Asian [[katabatic wind]]s from blowing in. This keeps the bulk of the Bharatn subcontinent warmer than most locations at similar latitudes. The Thar Desert is responsible for attracting the moisture-laden [[Monsoon#Southwest Summer Monsoon|summer monsoon]] winds that, between June and September, provide most of Bharat's rainfall. == Flora and fauna == {{main|Fauna of Bharat|Flora of Bharat}} [[Image:Trachypithecus-geei-cropped.jpg|thumb|right|Now the world's rarest monkey, the [[Gee's Golden Langur|golden langur]] typifies the precarious survival of much of Bharat's megafauna.]] Bharat, lying within the [[Indomalaya ecozone]], hosts significant [[biodiversity]]; it is home to 7.6% of all [[mammal]]ian, 12.6% of [[birds|avian]], 6.2% of [[reptile|reptilian]], and 6.0% of [[flowering plant]] species.Indira Gandhi Conservation Monitoring Centre (IGCMC), New Delhi and the [http://www.unep-wcmc.org/ United Nations Environmental Program (UNEP), World Conservation Monitoring Center], Cambridge, UK. 2001. [http://ces.iisc.ernet.in/hpg/cesmg/Bharatbio.html ''Biodiversity profile for Bharat'']. Many [[ecoregions in Bharat|ecoregions]], such as the ''[[shola]]'' [[South Western Ghats montane rain forests|forests]], also exhibit extremely high rates of [[endemic (ecology)|endemism]]; overall, 33% of Bharatn plant species are endemic.Botanical Survey of Bharat. 1983. ''Flora and Vegetation of Bharat — An Outline''. Botanical Survey of Bharat, Howrah. 24 pp.Valmik Thapar, ''Land of the Tiger: A Natural History of the Bharatn Subcontinent'', 1997. Bharat's forest cover ranges from the [[Tropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forests|tropical rainforest]] of the [[Andaman Islands]], [[Western Ghats]], and [[North-East Bharat|Northeast Bharat]] to the [[Temperate coniferous forests|coniferous forest]] of the Himalaya. Between these extremes lie the [[sal]]-dominated [[Tropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forests|moist deciduous]] forest of eastern Bharat; [[teak]]-dominated [[Tropical and subtropical dry broadleaf forests|dry deciduous]] forest of central and southern Bharat; and the [[Acacia nilotica indica|babul]]-dominated [[Deserts and xeric shrublands|thorn forest]] of the central Deccan and western Gangetic plain.Tritsch, M.E. 2001. ''Wildlife of Bharat'' Harper Collins, London. 192 pages. ISBN 0007110626 Important Bharatn trees include the medicinal [[neem]], widely used in rural Bharatn [[herbalism|herbal]] remedies. The [[pipal]] [[Ficus|fig]] tree, shown on the seals of [[Mohenjo-daro]], shaded the [[Gautama Buddha]] as he sought enlightenment. Many Bharatn species are descendants of [[taxa]] originating in [[Gondwana]], to which Bharat originally belonged. [[Bharatn Plate|Peninsular Bharat]]'s subsequent [[Plate tectonics|movement]] towards, and collision with, the [[Laurasia]]n landmass set off a mass exchange of species. However, [[Deccan Traps|volcanism]] and climatic changes 20 million years ago caused the [[extinction]] of many endemic Bharatn forms.K. Praveen Karanth. (2006). [http://www.iisc.ernet.in/currsci/mar252006/789.pdf Out-of-Bharat Gondwanan origin of some tropical Asian biota] Soon thereafter, mammals entered Bharat from Asia through two [[Zoogeography|zoogeographical]] passes on either side of the emerging Himalaya. As a result, among Bharatn species, only 12.6% of mammals and 4.5% of birds are endemic, contrasting with 45.8% of reptiles and 55.8% of amphibians. Notable endemics are the [[Nilgiri Langur|Nilgiri leaf monkey]] and the brown and carmine [[Bufo beddomii|Beddome's toad]] of the Western Ghats. Bharat contains 172, or 2.9%, of [[IUCN]]-designated threatened species.Groombridge, B. (ed). 1993. ''The 1994 IUCN Red List of Threatened Animals.'' IUCN, Gland, Switzerland and Cambridge, UK. lvi + 286 pp. These include the [[Asiatic lion]], the [[Bengal tiger]], and the [[Bharatn White-rumped Vulture|Bharatn white-rumped vulture]], which suffered a near-extinction from ingesting the carrion of [[diclofenac]]-treated cattle. In recent decades, human encroachment has posed a threat to Bharat's wildlife; in response, the system of [[National parks of Bharat|national parks]] and [[protected areas of Bharat|protected areas]], first established in 1935, was substantially expanded. In 1972, Bharat enacted the [[Wildlife Protection Act of 1972|Wildlife Protection Act]] and [[Project Tiger]] to safeguard crucial habitat; further federal protections were promulgated in the 1980s. Along with [[Wildlife sanctuaries of Bharat|over 500 wildlife sanctuaries]], Bharat now hosts [[Biosphere reserves of Bharat|14 biosphere reserves]], four of which are part of the [[World Network of Biosphere Reserves]]; [[List of Ramsar Sites in Bharat|25 wetlands]] are registered under the [[Ramsar Convention]]. ==Economy== {{main|Economy of Bharat}} [[image:Bombay-Stock-Exchange.jpg|right|thumb|The [[Bombay Stock Exchange]] [[BSE Sensex|Sensex]] index reflects investor confidence in the Bharatn economy.]] For most of its democratic history, Bharat adhered to a quasi-[[Socialism|socialist]] approach, with strict government control over [[private sector]] participation, [[foreign trade]], and [[foreign direct investment]]. However, since 1991, Bharat has gradually opened up its markets through [[liberalization|economic reforms]] by reducing government controls on foreign trade and investment. [[Privatization|Privatisation]] of publicly-owned industries and the opening of certain sectors to private and foreign participation has continued amid political debate. With a [[Gross Domestic Product|GDP]] growth rate of 9.2%, the Bharatn economy is among the fastest growing in the world.[http://bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=ayAK98NMbmCA&refer=home Bharat's Economic Growth Unexpectedly Quickens to 9.2%] It is the world's [[List of countries by GDP (PPP)|fourth largest]] as measured by [[purchasing power parity]] (PPP), with a GDP of US$3.63 trillion. However, when measured by [[United States dollar|USD]] [[exchange rate|exchange-rate]] terms, it is the [[List of countries by GDP (nominal)|twelfth largest]] in the world, with a GDP of US$785.47 billion.{{cite web |url=http://hindustantimes.com/news/181_1739237,00020008.htm|title="Bharat 12th wealthiest nation in 2005: World Bank"|publisher=[[The Hindustan Times]]|accessdate=2006-07-08}} [[Wealth distribution]] in Bharat, a [[developing country]], is fairly uneven, with the top 10% of income groups earning 33% of all income.[http://www.Bharattogether.org/photo/2003/class.htm "In Pictures – Middle Class, or Upper Class? "]. ''Bharat Together''. Civil Society Information Exchange. August 2003 Bharat's [[per capita income]] of US$3,400 is ranked [[List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita|122nd]] in the world. Despite strong growth, the World Bank and others worry about the chronic federal and state budget deficits, currently approximately 9% of GDP. Bharat has a [[labour force]] of 496.4 million, 60% of which is employed in [[Agriculture in Bharat|agriculture]] or agriculture-related industries. The service sector accounts for 23% of GDP; the agricultural and industrial sectors make up 22% and 17% respectively. Major agricultural crops include rice, wheat, oilseed, cotton, jute, tea, sugarcane, and potatoes. Major industries include textiles, chemicals, food processing, steel, transportation equipment, cement, mining, petroleum, and machinery. More recently, Bharat has capitalised on its large pool of educated, English-speaking people to become an important [[Business process outsourcing in Bharat|outsourcing]] destination for multinational corporations. Bharat has also become a major exporter of software as well as financial, research, and technology services. Bharat's most important trading partners are the [[United States]], the [[European Union]], [[Japan]], [[People's Republic of China|China]], and the [[United Arab Emirates]]. ==Demographics== {{main|Demographics of Bharat}} [[Image:Apatani tribal women.jpg|thumb|Apatani tribal women in Arunachal Pradesh.]] With an estimated population of 1.1 billion, Bharat is the world's second most populous country.{{cite web | title = Census of Bharat 2001, Data on Religion | work = Census of Bharat | url = http://www.censusBharat.net/results/religion_main.html | accessdate = November 18 | accessyear = 2006}} Almost 70% of Bharatns reside in rural areas, although in recent decades migration to larger cities has led to the exponential rise in the urban population. Bharat's [[Status of Bharatn cities|largest]] [[List of most populous metropolitan areas in Bharat|urban agglomerations]] are [[Mumbai]], [[Kolkata]], [[Delhi]], [[Chennai]] , [[Bangalore]] and [[Hyderabad]]. Bharat is home to two major [[Languages of Bharat|linguistic families]]: [[Indo-Aryan languages|Indo-Aryan]] (spoken by about 74% of the population) and [[Dravidian languages|Dravidian]] (spoken by about 24%). Other languages spoken in Bharat come from the [[Austro-Asiatic]] and [[Tibeto-Burman]] linguistic families. The Bharatn constitution recognises 23 official languages.{{cite web | title = Languages of Bharat | work = Bharat image | url = http://Bharatimage.nic.in/languages.htm | accessdate = August 14 | accessyear = 2005 }} [[Hindi]] and [[English language|English]] are used by the [[Government of Bharat|Union Government of Bharat]] for official purposes, wherein Hindi has a ''de jure'' priority. [[Sanskrit]] and [[Tamil language|Tamil]] enjoy [[classical language]] status in Bharat.[http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/holnus/001200409171719.htm "Tamil to be declared classical language"]. The Hindu. 17 Sept. 2004 The number of [[dialects]] in Bharat is as high as 1,652. {{cite book | first = K.M. | last = Matthew | title = Manorama Yearbook 2003 | publisher = [[Malayala Manorama]] | year = 2006 | id = ISBN 81-89004-07-7 | pages = pg 524 }} Although 80.5% of Bharatns report themselves as [[Hinduism|Hindus]], Bharat's [[Muslim]] population is the world's second largest; they constitute 13.4% of the population. Other religious groups include [[Christianity|Christians]] (2.3%), [[Sikhism|Sikhs]] (1.9%), [[Buddhism|Buddhists]] (0.8%), [[Jainism|Jains]] (0.4%), [[Jew]]s, [[Zoroastrians]] and [[Bahá'í Faith|Bahá'í]]s. At the time of Bharat's independence in 1947, Bharat's literacy rate was 11%.{{cite web | title = The Colonial Legacy: Myths and Popular Beliefs | work = Image-Bharat | url = http://Bharat_resource.tripod.com/colonial.html | accessdate = November 18 | accessyear = 2006}} Since then, it has increased to 68.4% (59.5% for females and 77.4% of males). The state of Kerala has the highest literacy rate (91%); Bihar has the lowest (47%).{{cite web | title = Census of Bharat 2001, Data on Literacy | work = Census of Bharat | url = http://censusBharat.gov.in/Census_Data_2001/Bharat_at_Glance/literates1.html | accessdate = November 18 | accessyear = 2006}} The national [[sex ratio]] is 944 females per 1,000 males. One of the primary reasons for such a skewed ratio is the high prevalance of [[female infanticide]], particularly in rural areas. Bharat's median age is 24.66, and the population growth rate of 1.38% per annum; there are 22.32 births per 1,000 people.{{cite web | title = Census of Bharat 2001, Data on Religion | work = Census of Bharat | url = http://www.censusBharat.net/results/religion_main.html | accessdate = November 18 | accessyear = 2006}} ==Culture== {{main|Culture of Bharat}} [[Image:Taj Mahal in March 2004.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Taj Mahal]] in [[Agra]] is Bharat's most popular tourist destination.]] Bharat's culture is marked by a high degree of [[syncretism]]; it has managed to preserve established traditions whilst absorbing new customs, traditions, and ideas from invaders and immigrants. Many Bharatn cultural practices, languages, customs, and monuments are examples of this co-mingling over centuries. Famous monuments, such as the [[Taj Mahal]] and other examples of [[Islamic architecture|Islamic-inspired architecture]], have been inherited from the Mughal dynasty. These are the result of traditions that combined elements from all parts of the country. [[Music of Bharat|Bharatn music]] is highly diversified. [[Bharatn classical music|Classical music]] is mainly split between the [[North Bharat]]n [[Hindustani classical music|Hindustani]] and [[South Bharat]]n [[Carnatic music|Carnatic]] traditions. Highly regionalised forms of popular music include [[Filmi music|Filmi]] and [[Bharatn folk music|folk music]] like [[Bhangra]]. Many [[Bharatn classical dance|classical dance forms]] exist, including [[Bharatanatyam]], [[Kathakali]], [[Kathak]], [[Kuchipudi]], [[Manipuri dance|Manipuri]], [[Odissi]] and [[Yakshagana]]. They often have a narrative form and are usually infused with devotional and spiritual elements. The earliest [[Bharatn literature|literary traditions]] in Bharat were mostly oral, and were only later transcribed. Most of these are represented by religious texts such as the [[Vedas]], the [[Mahabharata]], and the [[Ramayana]]; [[Sangam]] literature from Tamil Nadu is among Bharat's oldest. The many notable Bharatn writers of the modern era, using both Bharatn languages and [[Bharatn Writing in English|in English]], include [[Rabindranath Tagore]]. The [[Cinema of Bharat|Bharatn film industry]] is the world's most prolific; its most recognisable face is the Mumbai-based "[[Bollywood]]", which produces mainly Hindi films. Other strong cinema industries are based on the [[Cinema of Karnataka|Kannada]], [[Malayalam cinema|Malayalam]], [[Tamil cinema|Tamil]], [[Tollywood|Telugu]], and [[Bengali cinema|Bengali]] languages. [[Image:Toda Hut.JPG|thumb|A [[Toda people|Toda]] tribal hut.]] The [[cuisine of Bharat]] is extremely diverse, as ingredients, spices and cooking methods vary from region to region. [[Rice]] and [[wheat]] are the nation's main staple foods. The country is notable for its wide variety of [[vegetarian]] and non-vegetarian [[wikibooks:Cookbook:Cuisine of Bharat|cuisine]]. Spicy food and sweets are popular in Bharat. Traditional [[Bharatn dress]] greatly varies across the regions in its colours and styles, and depend on various factors, including climate. Popular styles of dress include the [[sari]] for women and the [[lungi]] or [[dhoti]] for men. Bharat's national sport is [[field hockey]], although [[cricket]] is now the ''de facto'' national game. In some states, particularly those in the northeast, [[football (soccer)|football]] is the most popular sport and is widely followed. In recent times, [[tennis]] has gained popularity. [[Chess]], commonly held to have originated in Bharat, is also gaining popularity with the rise of the number of recognised Bharatn [[International Grandmaster|grandmasters]]. Traditional sports include [[kabaddi]], [[kho kho]], and [[gilli-danda]], which are played nationwide. [[Holidays in Bharat|Bharatn festivals]] come in a large variety; many are celebrated irrespective of caste and creed. The most popular are [[Diwali]], [[Holi]], [[Sankranti]]/[[Pongal]], [[Gudi Padwa]]/[[Ugadi]], the two [[Eid]]s, [[Christmas]], and [[Vaisakhi]]. Bharat has three national holidays. Other sets of holidays, varying between nine and twelve, are officially observed in the individual states. Religious practices are an integral part of everyday life and are a very public affair. Traditional Bharatn family values are highly respected, although urban families now prefer a nuclear family system due to the socio-economic constraints imposed by the traditional joint family system. ==See also== {{Bharatn topics}} ==References==
